help.p: Every time you click a tab (including the current one), your input is saved.
When you click "Finish Editing", your input is saved, and you return to the search interface where your record is displayed.
The record is saved inside the folder you marked before opening the editor or the folder from which you opened it for re-editing.
Be aware that you are only logged in for 30 minutes and that when your session times out, you will be returned to the search interface and what you have input without saving cannot be retrieved.
You can always see when your record was last saved, in the line above.
Note that if you reload the web page, your last edits are lost.
You can keep your session alive for another 30 minutes by clicking any tab. When your session is about to expire, you are prompted to keep it alive and given 5 minutes to react.
If you know that you may not be able to finish a record, it is best to click "Finish Editing" and return later to continue editing it.
You can continue editing the record by finding it and clicking the "Edit Record" button inside the record's detail view.
If you wish to discard your edits, click "Cancel Editing" at the bottom of the page. None of the edits you have made will then be saved and you will be shown the original record again.

"Constituent" is used to describe parts of the resource, except information that falls within the scope of the Table Of Contents element.
"Series" is used to describe a named series of which the resource is a part.
"Other Version" is used to describe other versions of the work contained in the resource.

The code or name of the organization that either created or modified the original record. This information can be useful to trace the provenance of a particular metadata record. The name or code should be pulled from an authoritative list and indicated in Authority. Record Content Source should be repeated for each code or name recorded.

Information about the metadata record.

This type of administrative information can help establish the provenance of a metadata record and may enable better interpretation of the content of the record. Record Information may also include information that is relevant only to the creating or managing institution. This type of administrative information can help establish the provenance of a metadata record and may enable better interpretation of the content of the record.
A description of the contents of a resource.
A Table Of Contents can be rendered e.g. with dashes separating the chapter titles.

Use of Table Of Contents should be determined by the complexity of the digital object and whether or not the information is readily available. If more structured information is needed, consider using Related Item with the type="constituent" field instead. Table Of Contents can also be used as an empty field with an XLink field to link to an external table of contents.
Abstract is used to record a succinct summary of some aspect of the content of the resource.
Use one Abstract in every record, except when Title Information serves as an adequate summary of the content of the resource.
When creating a record for a digital surrogate, record a summary of the content of the original resource. If only a portion of the resource was digitized, summarize only that portion.
A link may be supplied in lieu of or in addition to a summary of the content.
Repeat Abstract as many times as necessary.
Identifies data that cannot be shared outside the institution.
This attribute is used with shareable="no" for data that may be proprietary or is rights protected and should not be used outside of a local system (such as providing to harvesters).

Information about restrictions imposed on access to a resource is noted here.

Use Access Condition to indicate rights relating to access and use of digital resources. State clearly any restrictions on use of the digital resource, including explicitly mentioning lack of copyright restrictions when the digital resource is in the public domain. Also provide contact information for use by end users who wish to require permissions for publication, exhibit, or other types of dissemination.

An XLink may be supplied in lieu of or in addition to the content noted in Access Condition. If, for example, you maintain rights information relating to specific resources on a website, you may provide a URL for that website in lieu of a textual rights statement. When doing so, you should provide enough textual explanation in Access Condition, along with the URL, to make the purpose of the URL clear to end users.
Whenever possible, consider using a standard license such as Creative Commons and/or a rights expression language such as the Open Digital Rights Language (ODRL) specification.
Indicates the type of resource that the user will access when following the URL link.
This attribute is particularly useful to provide a flag in the context of OAI service providers harvesting metadata.
The following values may be used with the access attribute:

ul.li: preview – Indicates a link to a thumbnail or snippet of text.
raw object – Indicates a direct link to the object described (e.g., a jpg or pdf document). Used only when the object is represented by a single file.
object in context – Indicates a link to the object within the context of its environment (with associated metadata, navigation, etc.)

URL is for an electronic location from which the resource is available. It is recommended that all URLs used with the Location element be persistent.
Note that Identifier is used for persistent identifiers that may or may not be resolvable.

The Location element with the URL subelement may be used to indicate locations of additional versions of the digital resource such as thumbnails of the digital resource. It is recommended that in these cases the access attribute be used to help an aggregator determine what versions of the resource are available. Best practice is that the "primary display" URL is a link to the resource with its contextual material (for example metadata, navigation to the collection homepage). If the primary link to a resource is to a stand-alone version of the resource (such as a JPEG image only), an end user will have no context except for the metadata on the service provider's site. At a minimum, the URL should point to a page that contains the resource and a navigation bar that allows users to reach the collection homepage. It is highly desirable that this page also include the descriptive metadata for the resource.
Use of the access attribute is recommended with all instances of URL.
Indicates how the object represented by the link will be used.
This attribute may be used to indicate special purpose of the URL in the element, which may be marked as such using the access attribute.
The following values is defined:

ul.li: primary display – Indicates that the link is the most appropriate to display for end users.

primary – Added for consistency when usage was defined for several other elements. This value has the same definition as "primary display". The intent is that "primary display" will be depricated in favor of "primary" in a future MODS version. Use of " primary" instead of "primary display" is therefore recommended in this attribute.

Coordinates contains a statement of coordinates covered by the resource. One or more statements may be supplied. If one is supplied, it is a point (i.e., a single location); if two, it is a line; if more than two, it is a n-sided polygon where n=number of coordinates assigned. No three points should be co-linear, and coordinates should be supplied in polygon-traversal order.

Description contains a textual description for a name when this is necessary, for example, to distinguish it from other names.
The Display Form field makes it possible to display personal names in unstructured form. It typically renders a name as given on the resource.
For some applications, contractual agreements require that the form of the name provided on the resource be provided.
Display Label is used when additional text associated with a field is needed for display.
Display Label may be used whenever appropriate to indicate the preferred labeling when displayed. Include the text preferred and capitalisation, but do not include delimiters such as colons.

Information identifying the version of the resource. Resources that constitute the same edition generally embody essentially the same content. If no edition statement applies to the resource, leave Edition empty.
Dates can be expressed in several different formats. The following values are used with the Encoding: w3cdtf, iso8601, marc. The recommended encoding is w3cdtf.

In all three encodings, a specific year (e.g. "1938") is encoded in the same way; the three standards differ in how to encode time points of time year. According to w3cdtf dates follow the pattern: YYYY-MM-DD, i.e. with dashes between year, month and day, and with all years have four, all months two and all days two digits. If hours, minutes, and seconds are needed, the following pattern is used: YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss.
If Encoding is not given any value, the input is assumed to be textual. This means that any way of noting time can be used. If possible, use a coded value.
Encoding is used to note the encoding followed in the date notation.

The recommendation is to use the w3cdtf encoding. According to this encoding, dates are formatted in the following way:
Year: YYYY (e.g. 1997)
Year and month: YYYY-MM (e.g. 1997-07)
Complete date: YYYY-MM-DD (e.g. 1997-07-16)
For more options, use the Extended Date-Time Format (http://www.loc.gov/standards/datetime/).

Use a number from 1 to 5 to indicate how complete the record is.

A statement of the number and specific material of the units of the resource that express physical extent. A typical entry for a book might read "xiv, 213 p." A typical entry for a video might read "21 min."
Extent may be used with electronic resources, e.g. digitised collection of slides, to show how many slides constitute the resource.

The number of units and the material of the units of the resource that express physical extent. Typical entries for a book might read "xiv, 213 p.", "21 p. : ill", "2 v.", " 3, 5, 697 p". Use 'p.' for page, 'v.' for volume and 'ill.' for illustrations.
Extent may be used with other resources than paper publications. Supply appropriate units (not necessarily abbreviated) depending on the nature of the resource.
Note that the values are not analysed into separate fields, but written as a text string. The field is text-only and there are no more input options.
One could enter these values in other languages and scripts than English and Latin, but this is not recommended.
Use this subfield to record information in textual form. Use this subfield when other subfields will not capture the appropriate information.
Identifies the type of part.
There is no controlled list of part types.

A term that specifies the characteristics and general type of the content of the resource being catalogued. This field includes a high-level type that categorizes the material in a general way. More specific typing is done in the Genre field.

Information in Type Of Resource is about the original item. For example, in the case of a digitized photograph, Type Of Resource would apply to the analog original; in born-digital materials, it wouldapply to the original digital format.
Resource Type, Genre, and Form (under Physical Description) overlap to some extent.
There may be no value given for Type Of Resource if the Collection or Manuscript field is used and none of the enumerated values is appropriate.
"Yes" indicates that the resource is a collection.

A collection is defined as a multi-part group of resources. One example would be an anthology. If there are multiple resource types within the collection, these should be enumerated in separate Type Of Resource fields.
Collection and Manuscript are associated with a specific value used in Type Of Resource.

For example, an object which consists of a collection of maps with associated text would be represented by two instances of Type Of Resource. The first would be "Cartographic" with Collection "yes," and the second would be "Text" with Collection "No".
"Yes" indicates that the resource is handwritten or typescript.
The fields "collection" and "manuscript" are associated with a specific value used in Type Of Resource.
For example, an object which consists of a collection of maps with associated text would be represented by two instances of Type Of Resource.
The first would be "Cartographic" with Collection "yes," and the second would be "text" with Collection "No".

Name of any extraterrestrial entity or space, including solar systems, galaxies, star systems, and planets as well as geographic features of individual planets.
Frequency is used to note the publication pattern of the item. It is only used if the Issuance of the resource is "continuing".
One or more terms that characterise the resource as having a particular style, form, or content, such as artistic, musical, literary composition, etc.
Genre contains terms that give more specificity than the broad terms used in Type Of Resource.
If used in connection with a digital resource, Genre should be used to characterise the content of the digital resource rather than the digital resource itself.
The values should be chosen from a controlled vocabulary appropriate for the resource described. This source vocabulary should be indicated using the authority field.

Genre is a term that carries different specific meanings within different communities of practice, and the content of most information objects can be characterised by genre at different levels of granularity, either very broad or quite specific. For example, photographs and ambrotypes are both valid genre characterizations, depending on your perspective, for a specific type of direct positive photographic print. At the very least, provide a very broad genre term for materials being digitised.
Type of Resource, Genre, Form under Physical Description overlap to some degree.

Geographic Code includes a geographic area code associated with a resource. A geographic code that represents the same entity as a term in Geographic is included within the same Subject field.

This sub-field includes a hierarchical form of a place name relating to the content of the resource that is both readable by humans and parsable by machines. This form can be applied to the degree of specificity that is known or relevant and used to generate browseable hierarchies even when values are specified to different levels. Explicit inclusion of the complete hierarchy is of potential benefit for automated consultation of a gazetteer to derive map coordinates or to support a map-based interface for searching by country or state. This sub-field has no fields.
ID is used to link among records inside the database and to reference a field inside the database from outside the database.
A designation of a document segment type. Suggested values include series (of a periodical), volume, issue, chapter, section, paragraph, and track. Other values may be used as needed.

Use this field to indicate the type of the part described.

In Issuance one records how the resource is issued. It may be used with the following values: continuing and monographic.

A continuing resource is issued over time with no predetermined conclusion. Continuing resources include serials/periodicals and ongoing integrating resources, i.e. those that are continuously updated. A monographic resource is either complete in one part or intended to be completed in a finite number of separate parts.

One can record different events that may be important in the life of a resource in a number of different date fields. When multiple date fields apply but would contain identical data, one may choose to use only one of the relevant date fields. In this case, mark one and only one such date field as a key date by choosing "date is key date" in Key Date.

If you are using different Language values inside Origin Information, apply Language to each field and leave Language empty under Origin Information.
Here the language of the contents of the described resource as a whole is noted.

Language may also be expressed in relation to a single field, by means of the Language field, in order to note the language used in a particular field. This is only necessary if the language used in the field in question (e.g. in an alternative title) is different from the language noted in Resource Language.

Cataloging Language under Record Information is used to note the language used in the record itself. Cataloging Language is not the Resource Language, but of the metadata describing a resource, i.e. the record you are working on or looking at now. The Language of Cataloging is assumed to be English; if you wish to note another Language of Cataloging, click "Show All" to display the required tab..

At least one Resource Language field is required for all resources in which language is primary to understanding the resource. These resources include textual resources, but also audio and video resources with spoken word components.

Although Language is usually not required for non-textual resources such as images, it could be used effectively for such resources when language is a component. Examples of the latter might include a photograph of a sign with text or a monument with an inscription.

The Language field is optional for resources in which language is important to understanding the resource, but not primary. For example, the caption of a photograph may in some instances be important to understanding the photograph, but not primary. If the content of the resource is in more than one language, Language is repeated for each language employed.

Language Term specifies the language(s) of the content of the resource. It may be expressed in textual or coded form. If in coded form, the source of the code should be indicated in the value of the authority field. If no authority is given, it is assumed that the content is textual, i.e. that the Type is "text". If there is more than one representation of the same language, e.g. using different forms of the same language (code or text) or from different authorities, Language Term is repeated within the Language container.

Location identifies the institution or repository holding the resource, or a remote location in the form of a URL where the resource is available. In the case of a physical resource, information is noted about what the institution identified in Physical Location holds of the resource in question and its specific location within the institution.

Holdings information consists of copy-specific information about the resource, information about the specific location within an institution, version information, and other information that is peculiar to the institution.

Name Part includes each part of the name. Parsing is used to parse parts of a personal name into family/surname and given name/forename, as well as terms of address, but it is also used to indicate a date associated with the name and to parse the parts of a corporate name.
The parsing performed is indicated by the Type field. This field takes the following values: Date, Family, Given, Terms Of Address.

"Date" is used to note dates that are not integral parts of a name. For dates within e.g. a conference name, do not use this field to separate the date, since it is an integral part of the name of the conference. The birth date associated with a personal name, however, is not an integral part of the name, but can be added to distinguish the name from others, so it does include a separate Name Part with a Type of "Date".
"Family" is used for the family name or surname of a person.
"Given" is used for the given name or forename of a person.
"Terms Of Address" is used to record titles and enumeration associated with a name, such as "Jr.", "II", etc.

If you do not know how to break up a name or if a name is not constructed according to the family name/given name pattern, leave the Type of the Name Part blank and enter the whole name as it occurs in one Name Part.
Name-Title Group can be used with Name and Title Information to enable an explicit link between a name and a title when that is desirable.
The same value is assigned to this attribute for the two elements. This attribute is used to link names to uniform titles when the name-uniform title combination is an authority controlled heading.

Non Sort contains characters, including initial articles (typically "A" and "The" in English), punctuation, and spaces that appear at the beginning of a title that should be ignored when indexing and sorting.

A note contains general information relating to a resource.

Occupation includes a term that is descriptive of the occupation reflected in the contents of the described materials. The designation of physical parts of a resource in a detailed form. Part is used to provide detailed description of the physical parts of a resource. It may be used as a top level field to designate the physical parts or under Related Item. If used under Related Item, Part records the location of a part within a host/parent item. If used as a top level field, Part records a part of a resource, usually because the library is not in possession of the whole resource.

Use Part when the record in question refers to either a physical or structural part of a resource, rather than an intellectual part. An intellectual part of a resource should be recorded in various fields under Title. A newspaper issue would e.g. generally be indicated with Part, rather than indicating the issue number as part of the title. Other examples include an issue of a journal or a single story from a collection. Part as a top level field would also be used to describe one reel of microfilm in a set, or in any other case in which the part being described is not an intellectual whole by itself. When in doubt, and only part numbers and/or part names are needed, use Part Number and/or Part Name under Title under Title Information.
Part is used here to record the various parts of one publication inside another publication.
Most publications only have one part. An article may have several instalments, but most articles, contributions and book reviews are published as a whole.
For articles and book reviews, the volume and issue, the year of publication and the page extent are noted.
For contributions to edited volumes, the volume (if relevant) and the page extent are noted.
Enter here information regarding in which volume of the edited volume the contribution occurs, if the edited volume is in several volumes.
Enter also information regarding the page extent of the contribution.

Part Name is used for a part or section name of a title. Use Part Name when a part name is present, rather than including the part name in the text of Title. Use Part Name to describe the section or division titles of a digital object (for example, a chapter title, episode name, or an audio or video clip).
If a resource has multiple parts, each with its own Part Name, the work should be catalogued in as many records as there are Part Names.
When representing the Part Name, do not include punctuation at the end of the preceding field intended to separate the part name from previous parts of the title.
Part Number is used for a part or section number in a title.
Use Part Number when a part number is present, rather than including the part number in the text of the Title.
A Part Number does not have to be a digit, i.e. "First Part" may be the contents of the Part Number field if this is how it occurs on the title page.
Part Number may describe the section of an digital object (for example, an episode number or an audio or video clip).
When using Part Number, do not include punctuation at the end of the preceding field intended to separate the part number from previous parts of the title.

Enter here information related to the edited volume that the contribution you are cataloguing occurs in.

This information falls into two groups:
general information on the edited volume
specific information on the location of the contribution in the edited volume

There are two ways you can supply this information:
you can fill out the title, editors, etc. of the edited volume
you can supply the ID number of the edited volume and then fill out the information on the location of the contribution in the edited volume

If you are cataloguing several contributions from the same edited volume, it is a good idea first to catalogue the edited volume. This will save you time and produce a more ordered bibliography. When you have finished with cataloguing the edited volume, you can then choose "Create Related Record" in the detail view for the record in question. The ID number for the edited volume will then automatically be inserted and you only have to fill out the information particular to the contribution itself. If you are only cataloguing one contribution, you can also follow this way - others may then use your record (if you make it available to them) and catalogue other contributions in the same edited volume, by finding it and clicking "Create Related MODS Record".

If you choose to enter the information concerning the edited volume inside the record for the contribution, that is, not to use XLink, this is also fine. If you later decide to use the ID of the record for the edited volume, you may insert its ID in the XLink field.
Enter here information related to the monograph series that the book you are cataloguing occurs in.

general information on the monograph series
specific information on the place (number) of the book within the monograph series

There are two ways you can supply this information:
you can fill out the title, editors, etc. of the monograph series on this form
you can supply the ID number of a record cataloguing the monograph series and then fill out the information on the place (number) of the book within the monograph series
In connection with monograph series, the first approach is the most common.

If you enter the information concerning the monograph series inside the record for the book, that is, not to use the ID of the series, you can later decide to use the ID of the record for the monograph series, by inserting its ID in the XLink field and removing the information you have supplied about the title of the monograph series.

If you are cataloguing several books from the same series, it is a good idea first to catalogue the series. This will save you time and produce a more ordered bibliography. When you have finished with cataloguing the series, you can choose "Create Related MODS Record" in the detail view for the record in question. The ID number for the series will then automatically be inserted and you only have to fill out the information particular to the book itself (its place within the series and so on). If you are only cataloguing one book, you can also follow this way - others may then use your record (if you make it available to them) and catalogue other books in the same series, by finding it and likewise clicking "Create Related MODS Record".

A Subject is a term or a phrase that represents the primary topic(s) on which a work is focused. Use at least one Subject field in each record to allow retrieval of the record by its contents. Enter as many specific terms as necessary to capture the contents. Be consistent in the formatting of Subject terms.
A publication is often on a number of different subjects. If these are separate subjects, repeat the Subject instead of storing diverse information inside one Subject.
Values for Subject indicate which contents is found within or represented by the work, and these values typically answer such questions as who, what, where, and when.

While it is allowed to place multiple values in a single Subject field, such as within on Topic field, it is the preferred practice to split up Subject terms into separate sub-fields, each of which answer the question of who, what, where, and when in relation to the resource being catalogued. Analyse as much as possible.

A Subject is basically composed of a Topic, a Place reference and a Time reference. All these fields are optional, that is, one can have a Topic without any Place or Time reference, and one can have a Place reference without a Topic or a Time reference. To have a Time reference all on its own would be a little unusual, but if period labels are used, this might still be acceptable.

Topics can be divided into different kinds: "plain" Topics, Name topics and Work topics. "Plain" topics are references to abstract or concrete entities that are not persons or organisations or works created by these. Topics of this kind are "beauty" or "bicycle", "democracy" or "doors". No distinction is made between abstract or concrete topics.

In addition to plain topics, a person or an institution can serve as topic, examples being "George Washington" or "United Nations." These are identified by their names. If a work of literature or art, or any other creation, serves as topic, it is identified by its title. These three subtypes address different aspects of the "what" of a subject.

In order not to complicate matters, no notice is here taken of language, script, transliteration, etc. If you need to enter information using these categories, select the Subjects tab on Content Description Forms.
The "where" of a subject can be expressed in a number of ways. "Place" simply contains the name of the place.

"Time", the answer to "when," can be encoded in a number of different ways. The recommendation is to use the w3cdtf encoding. According to this encoding, dates are formatted in the following way: Year: YYYY (e.g. 1997); Year and month: YYYY-MM (e.g. 1997-07); Complete date: YYYY-MM-DD (e.g. 1997-07-16).
Date ranges are indicated using "start" and "end" in Point. If a date range is open to one side, leave that side blank. If the date is completely unknown, leave the Date field blank.

In Time one can also use period designations, such as "the Middle Ages" and "Industrialisation," with the dangers of differing construals of what these labels denote. If you enter a time designation which uses a designation of this type, choose "text" in type.
More input options can be accessed by clicking the Subjects tab on Content Description Forms.
Subtitle is used to record a part of a title that is secondary to the core title.

Title Information is used under Subject to note when the resource catalogued is about another resource with a title, e.g. when it is a book about another book or an article about a work of art. The aim is here not to refer to a concrete publication, but to a more abstract work. This may be a written work, such as "Hamlet", a work of art, such a "Guernica", or a work of music, such as "The Wall", etc.

(Note that there is no regular way of recording authorship, editorship and so on. If a person or institution needs to be pointed to in order to identify a work, one can add such a reference in Persons and Institutions as Topic, but there is no place to specify the relation of the person or institution to the work.).

A Title Information consists of a Title and fields that relate to it. A Title may have a Subtitle, usually an expansion of the Title proper. Use Topic to indicate any primary subjects that do not fit into the Place, Time, Works as Topics, or Persons and Institutions as Topics sub-fields. In general, abstract nouns should be used. Add as many Topic fields as you need in order to analyse your topic. The relation between the different fields is not specified, but one may start with more abstract terms and move to more specific terms, within the same Subject.

Before adding a Topic, consider whether what you are cataloguing is not rather another Subject. There are no hard-and-fast rules here, but it is best to analyse as much as possible, i.e. if the term to be entered as a Topic is not a specification of the Topic term already entered, one should probably add another Subject instead of another Topic.

The language used within Title Information is specified here, if this language is different from the language noted in Language of Resource. xml:lang is used to specify the language used within a field, using specifications in RFC 3066. RFC 3066 uses the two-character ISO 639-1 codes along with three-character ISO 639-2 codes for those languages not given in 639-1.
The recommendation is not to use xml:lang, but to use Language.
Reformatting Quality indicates an overall assessment of the physical quality of an electronic resource in relation to its intended use.
The following values may be used: access, preservation and replacement.

li.item: "access" indicates that the electronic resource is intended to support current electronic access to the original item (i.e., reference use), but is not sufficient to serve as a preservation copy.
"preservation" indicates that the electronic resource was created via reformatting to help preserve the original item. The capture and storage techniques ensure high-quality, long-term protection.
"replacement" indicates that the electronic resource is of high enough quality to serve as a replacement if the original is lost, damaged, or destroyed.
